'''''Astraeus pteridis''''' is a species of [[Astraeus (genus)|false earthstar]] in the family [[Diplocystaceae]]. It was described by American mycologist [[Cornelius Lott Shear]] in 1902 under the name ''Scleroderma pteridis''.<ref name=Shear1902/> [[Sanford Myron Zeller]] transferred it to ''[[Astraeus]]'' in a 1948 publication. It is found in [[North America]].<ref name=Zeller1948/> ''A. pteridis'' was previously frequently confused with the supposedly cosmopolitan ''[[Astraeus hygrometricus|A. hygrometricus]]'', now shown to be found only in Europe.

== Distribution ==
A molecular [[Phylogenetics|phylogenetic]] study from 2013 resulted in the application of the name ''A. pteridis'' to the larger ''Astraeus'' found in the Pacific Northwest region of North America. ''A. pteridis'' has also been found in the [[Canary Islands]], [[Madeira]], and [[Argentina]], which share historical connections to [[Lusitania]]. It may be widely distributed or have been [[Species translocation|translocated]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Phosri|first=Cherdchai|last2=Martín|first2=María P.|last3=Watling|first3=Roy|date=Dec 2013|title=Astraeus: hidden dimensions|journal=IMA Fungus|volume=4|issue=2|pages=347–356|doi=10.5598/imafungus.2013.04.02.13|issn=2210-6340|pmc=3905946|pmid=24563840}}</ref>

== Morphology ==
''A. pteridis'' closely resembles ''A. hygrometricus'', though it is larger, reaching 5 to 15 cm (2.0 to 5.9 in) or more when expanded, and often has a more pronounced [[areolate]] pattern on the inner surface of the rays. <ref>{{Cite book|title=Mushrooms demystified : a comprehensive guide to the fleshy fungi|last=Arora|first=David|date=1986|publisher=Ten Speed Press|isbn=978-0898151701|edition=2nd|location=Berkeley|pages=706|oclc=13702933}}</ref>Within ''[[Astraeus (fungus)|Astraeus]]'', ''A. pteridis'' is most closely related to ''[[Astraeus morganii|A. morganii]].'' Like other Astraeus, it is [[Hygroscopy|hygroscopic]], with rays expanding in humid conditions and closing in arid conditions. It is not typically considered edible.
